standards.header: Qualified physician is responsible for managing the neonatal intensive care unit.

details.header: The department head is a qualified Pediatrician with experience in neonatology (for level 1 and 2 NICU) and certified neonatologist (for level3 NICU).
The department head takes the overall responsibility for the operation of the unit.

standards.header: The neonatal intensive care unit nurse manager is a qualified registered nurse.

details.header: The nurse manager is qualified by education, training, and experience in neonatal intensive care.

The nurse manager develops and collaborates with NICU physicians and other departments as needed for developing policies and procedures for the unit (e.g., policies and practices related to infection control).

standards.header: Medical and nursing staff working in the neonatal intensive care unit have the appropriate cardiac life support training.

details.header: Medical staff working in neonatal intensive care unit are certified in Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP).
Nursing staff working in the neonatal intensive care unit are certified in Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP).

standards.header: The neonatal intensive care unit is covered by qualified physicians.

details.header: The neonatal intensive care unit is covered twenty four hours a day, seven days a week by qualified neonatal intensive care physicians.
For a Level 3 unit, there is certified neonatologist to cover the unit during the on call hours.

standards.header: The neonatal intensive care unit has admission and discharge criteria.

details.header: The neonatal intensive care unit identifies its own population based on age and diagnosis related groups.
The admission and discharge criteria are defined in writing.
Criteria for admission are based on physiological parameters.
The criteria are developed collaboratively between relevant staff.

standards.header: Patient care in the neonatal intensive care unit is coordinated.

details.header: There is a documented evidence of handover between physicians at change of shift.
There is a documented evidence of handover between nurses at change of shift.
There is a documented evidence of handover between neonatal intensive care nurse and unit nurse at the time of transfer to a lower acuity of care.

standards.header: Patient care in the neonatal intensive care unit is provided using a multidisciplinary approach.

details.header: The multidisciplinary team includes both NICU as well as non NICU members. This includes but not is limited to: NICU physician, NICU nurse, clinical pharmacist, respiratory therapist, and dietitian.
Medically necessary services are readily available and accessible at all times.
Care is coordinated amongst the multidisciplinary team members and documented in the patient’s medical record.

standards.header: The admission and discharge processes in the neonatal intensive care unit are coordinated.

details.header: A summary of the neonatal intensive care stay is written by the NICU physician and made available at the time of discharge from critical care to a lower acuity level.
There is documented evidence of handover between the neonatal intensive care physician and the unit physician at the time of transfer to a lower acuity of care.
When the patient is discharged from the unit, the neonatal intensive care unit physician ensures that the receiving team is well informed about the patient’s status and ongoing patient needs.
details: The patient’s plan of care and medications are written in detail by the physician including how to continue them on the floor.
Any special care requirements are documented in the medical record.

standards.header: Nursing staffing plans are available in the neonatal intensive care unit.

details.header: The nursing staffing plans demonstrate an evidence based nursing to patient ratio.
The nursing staffing plans are matching the patient volume and patient acuity.

standards.header: Nursing staff in the neonatal intensive care unit receive continuous training with competency assessment.

details.header: Nursing staff in the NICU intensive care unit receive training and education on the following general and intensive care related needs:
details: Assisting physicians in the different procedures performed in the neonatal intensive care unit including securing central lines access.
Recognizing critical ECG changes including arrhythmias.
Assisting physician in placing central lines or arterial lines and /or umbilical arterial/venous lines.
Obtaining arterial blood gas samples and blood drawing from umbilical catheters.

Knowledgeofdosagerange,sideeffectsandcomplicationsofcommonlyused medications such as surfactant and high alert medications used in neonatal care including vasopressors, narcotics, and controlled medications.
Care of the terminally ill and end of life patients.

details.header: There is ongoing competency assessment for the nursing staff (e.g., written test, return demonstration).
The competency assessment of the nursing staff is documented.

standards.header: The neonatal intensive care unit has adequate equipment, supplies, and diagnostic services.

details.header: There are isolation rooms with at least one negative pressure room.
The following equipment are available:
details: Crash cart that includes defibrillator, all emergency supplies, and medications as appropriate to neonates.
ECG monitor, pulse oximetry, and vital signs monitor.
Intravenous infusion and blood transfusion pumps.

details.header: The availability and functionality of all tools and equipment are checked daily.
Equipment are cleaned and disinfected daily and as needed.
Portable equipment for safe patient transports are available.
Laboratory and imaging services are available to meet the needs of patients receiving neonatal intensive care.

standards.header: Policies and procedures are available to guide the work in the neonatal intensive care unit.

details.header: There are policies and procedures for medical and nursing initial assessment and re-assessment requirements, including time frames for completion of initial assessments and frequency of re- assessments.
There are policies and procedures for monitoring of patient circulation, respiration, and oxygenation.
There are evidence-based criteria for intubation, weaning off ventilator and extubation.
There are policies and procedures for handover procedure between staff in between shifts and at discharge to a lower acuity of care.
There are policies and procedures for infection control practices including isolation.
There are policies and procedures for the use of neonatal Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) for more sick patients.
There are policies and procedures for dealing with ethical issues (e.g., NoCodepolicy, endoflife issues, and organ donation).
Policies are collaboratively developed by the appropriate staff.

standards.header: Infection control standards are strictly implemented and supervised in the neonatal intensive care unit.

details.header: The neonatal intensive care unit environment is maintained clean and neat at all times.
Infection control standards are strictly applied in the neonatal intensive care unit (e.g., hand hygiene and use of personal protective equipment).
Neonatal intensive care unit staff members adopt and implement care bundle for prevention of epidemiologically significant healthcare associated infections.
